text:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

Author's Introduction

Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and the [good] end is for the righteous, and there is no aggression except against the wrongdoers. Prayers and peace be upon the best of His creation, our master Muhammad, and upon all his family and companions, and their followers among the drawn-near allies (Awliya), and the people of Your obedience whom You have chosen over many of Your believing servants, and singled them out for nearness to Your Presence, and acquainted them with some of Your knowledge, and honored them with Tawhid (Monotheism), obedience, guidance, and success. You made them successors to Your prophets in miracles, and manifested through them karamat (miraculous gifts) to the creation. You established them to bear the tribulations that descend upon creation from the heavens; so they are patient in bearing them, complying with what You established them in, satisfied with You, and rectifying their regions. They judge for the interests of the servants by Your command, following the path of reality (Haqiqah). The people of knowledge follow their sayings and deeds for the Sharia (Divine Law), and emulate them. They are the light of the world and its lamps; no one walks a path except by the light of those lamps. Through them we are guided, their path we emulate, and by their secret we seek rain. They are circling in all regions of the earth, witnessing the Divine Presence, and by the permission of their Lord, removing distress from the servants. Each of them has a rank he upholds by the permission of the Lord of the Worlds. They are persistent in these states, not heedless of the remembrance of Allah Almighty, famous by the secret, elevated above creation in the knowledge of Tawhid and the knowledge of Haqiqah. Their hearts and limbs are filled with faith, varying in faith according to their ranks in the stations of nearness.

"Types of Tawhid and Divisions of Guidance"

Types of Tawhid
The types of Tawhid are three: Knowing that Allah Almighty is unique in planning, influence, and the Tawhid of Dominion, and His uniqueness, Glory be to Him, in complete sovereignty and general governance.
Tawhid of Divinity (Uluhiyyah) is through three matters:
First: That He be deified such that majesty and love take over the heart so that no room remains in it for other than Him.
Second: That one does not resort in needs, for repelling harm or bringing benefit, except to Him.
Third: That one hastens to His answers and what pleases Him.

The divisions of Guidance are also three:
The first meaning: The creation of Tawhid in the heart, which is the knowledge of Allah Almighty. Allah Almighty created three things in the heart:
1. The light of knowledge (Ma'rifah).
2. The light of love.
3. The light of intellect.

Second: From the divisions of guidance: Guidance meaning persistence in faith and steadfastness upon it. From this is the saying of the monotheist: (Guide us to the straight path), meaning grant us persistence upon it. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to frequently say: "O Turner of hearts, make my heart steadfast on Your religion." And among his supplications was: "O Director of hearts, direct our hearts to Your obedience." The difference between this and the first is: In the first, he asks for persistence and steadfastness on faith, and in the second, he asks that He directs his heart to His obedience. In it is a reference to Tawfiq (success granted by Allah), which is assistance in performing what Allah Almighty commanded and abandoning what He forbade. Tawfiq is the servant's performance of obedience according to what his Lord commanded. If he performs it in accordance with His command, then Tawfiq has occurred. Whenever he falls short, exceeds, or abandons an action, he has missed Tawfiq.
Since faith is not achieved except through Allah Almighty, Allah created in the servant's heart the light of love for faith, because love binds the beloved, for whoever loves something holds onto it. And since the beloved needs someone to protect it from his whispers and defend it from enemies—who are the devils from mankind and jinn calling to disbelief and worship of other than Allah Almighty—Allah Almighty gave the servant the light of intellect, which is the third of the lights, to protect the faith He made beloved to him and the blessings Allah Almighty bestowed upon us, which are: the light of knowledge, the light of love, and the light of intellect. These were mentioned previously, and Allah Almighty mentioned them in Surah Al-Hujurat.
The reference to the light of knowledge is in His saying: (And know that among you is the Messenger of Allah), wherein is the command to know the Messenger and the Sender.
His saying: (But Allah has endeared to you the faith and has made it pleasing in your hearts) is a reference to the light of binding love.
And His saying: (And has made hateful to you disbelief, defiance, and disobedience) is a reference to the light of intellect. By this, the whispering of the servant and diseases of the heart such as oppression, envy, arrogance, hatred, mockery, backbiting, gossip, and others are repelled. By the light of intellect, the whispering of Satan and all innovations are repelled. By the light of intellect, faith is protected from what disputes with it and confuses it from the disturbances that drag one to disbelief, sins, and following desires. It has been said: Sins are the courier of disbelief, and whoever follows desires has planted the tree of regrets in his heart.

The third division of Guidance: That it is in the meaning of clarification (Bayan). Allah Almighty said: (And indeed, you guide to a straight path). The intent here regarding the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, is the clarification that leads to believing the truth as truth and falsehood as falsehood.
Know that the first two divisions do not occur from other than Allah Almighty. The Guide is Allah: Allah Almighty said: (Indeed, you do not guide whom you like), meaning you do not create guidance in the heart of one from whom it is veiled, but Allah guides whom He wills. O Allah, guide us among those You have guided. End of the Sheikh's speech.

Chapter
On the Prohibition of Sitting with Young Boys and Women, Consorting with them, and Looking at them

Allah Almighty said: (Tell the believing men to reduce [some] of their vision and guard their private parts).

The Eye is the Head of the Senses bringing thoughts:
Al-Qurtubi said in *Al-Gharib al-Muntaqa*: Know that the head of your senses bringing thoughts to you, which almost indicates you without speech, expresses your intention without words, and almost leads the rest of the limbs of your body, is the sense of sight. Its position in the body is like the position of the sun in the world. It is the sense that perceives its object instantly without time; I mean that its perception of what is near is as fast as its perception of what is far, and there is no time between its near and far perception. The rest of the senses perceive with time, and perception ceases with the absence of the perceived object. Just as the eye is the head of the senses, so too disciplining it by controlling its glances, condemning its staring, and managing its glancing is among the noblest actions crossing over to praiseworthy discipline, indicative of the nobility of the soul and generosity of ambition.

Neglecting its discipline and what results from it:
According to that, neglecting it and casting its ray on what is not lawful and not praiseworthy is among the ugliest actions distancing from good, leading to slipping, indicative of the baseness of the soul and vileness of ambition. So make your covenant regarding what you cast your gaze upon among the first of your actions that you begin reforming in yourself. Know that it is the most fearful of your senses for you, and the closest of them to seizing your mind, for in its objects are the beauty of forms, the goodness of bodies, the grace of movements, the splendor of compositions, the colors of faces, and the brocades of faces which are the most tempting of perceived things in their beauty, the most destructive in entry to hearts, and the closest means to souls. Therefore, worshippers often need to isolate themselves from groups and flee from thoughts.

Beware the deception of Satan!
Beware in this matter that Satan deceives you, removing patience from your soul, and cutting off the strength in your resolve. He places in you the material for looking and staring at what is not lawful, and glancing with the pretext of considering what is not permissible to consider in the creation of Allah Almighty, marveling at the wonder of its structure and the elegance of its composition. He gradually leads you, deceiving, to where temptation can enable itself from your eye, and establish its position in your heart.

Minor sins lead to major sins:
If you are heedless for a little while, enabling him from your eye, he will inevitably cast you either into fighting the impulses of your desire—fighting which you were free from occupying yourself with—or into submission to them. And when you are driven into the depths of temptations, there is no limit or end to them, for the eye is never satiated with looking, and the action of its desires is like the action of fire, which is its perceived object; the more wood is added, the more it flames.

How to flee?
Precaution against the disliked is by guarding against the first of its causes. Ascending to every beautiful thing is like descending to every ugly thing; the steps of descent, the first of them is close to what follows it, whether ascending or descending. The most beneficial prudence and consideration is in distinguishing the causes from which matters are generated. As for distinguishing matters at their end, that is not hidden from an ignorant person, let alone a scholar.

Your soul blames you!
Know that it may bequeath you idleness and lead you to stupidity by prolonging the stare at what does not concern you, and looking at what does not benefit you. Likewise, it may judge you in some cases with silliness, and vileness blames you in the likes of being distracted by every ugly thing and looking at every hideous thing. Likewise, it may witness against you in some actions with arrogance and vanity, and in some with piety and humility.

The reins of the matter are in your hand!
So compel it to the best actions you praise in others, and clothe it in the most beautiful garments you find beautiful on others. Understand the places where you must lower it from what it desires to look at, and those where you must divert it to examining what you use. Which elegant sights bequeath it consideration, and which bequeath it temptation? Which ugly sights is approaching them knowledge and devotion, and which is silliness and degradation?

What if you lowered your gaze?

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Know that in lowering your gaze from looking at what is not safe lies a rest for the heart, a cutting off of evil, a reformation of the soul, and a cutting of material for whimsical will. Your lowering of the gaze connects you to the existence of your intellect, which is the origin of knowing your Lord, because knowledge of Him, Mighty and Majestic, is the product of sound intellect, and faith in Him, Mighty and Majestic, is the product of knowledge of Him. When the intellect is sound, knowledge grows, faith is truthful, and the heart rules over all limbs with acts of service. So contemplate—O my brother—your heart with sincerity, and be gentle in traveling the paths of safety from damaging afflictions and wandering thoughts.

How is the exit and escape?:
Know that the exit of directed vision is from beneficial intellect, the exit of indication is from intellectual knowledge, and the exit of thought is from the certainty of the heart. If looking at blessings persists, practical knowledge indicative of it supports it. Then knowledge falls upon it, so thought reveals what is in it of favor and benefit. Thus, souls become familiar with blessings, rejoice in their proximity, cut off from causes of [sinful] action, become solitary in their seclusion with their care, anxiety about other than them falls away, and connect with what preserves them and is intended by them. If the soul's knowledge of the Lord's blessings, Glorified and Exalted, is sound, the chest and heart expand for it, gratitude occurs, remembrance increases, joy and happiness are complete, pride becomes great, and life becomes pure and good.

Chapter
How do we catch up with the strivers and surpass the hasteners?

Advice of an experienced Sheikh!
Some Sheikhs said to their disciple: O my son, shall I not guide you to a deed, much of the deeds of the righteous, by which you catch up with the striving worker, even if you are slow? Guard your glance and your tongue while fulfilling rights; that is the work of those firmly grounded. If you want to surpass the hastening rider, even if you are slow, occupy your heart and tongue with the remembrance of Allah, while leaving [personal] fortunes; that is from the deeds of the truthful (Siddiqin). Worship Allah on the path of knowledge, you will be safe from afflictions, and be sincere to Him on the path of truthfulness, you will be raised in degrees.
Some worshippers looked at a boy and contemplated his beauty, so he was visited in his sleep and told: You will surely find its consequence after forty years.
Some wise men said: The heart is like a house with six doors.

What are the doors of the heart?
Then it was said to him: Beware that nothing enters upon you from one of these doors that corrupts the house for you. The heart is the house, and its doors are: the mouth, the tongue, the hearing, the sight, the two hands, and the two feet. Opening these doors without knowledge is a waste of the house, and closing this house is an obligation, and blocking every door of these doors is an obligation, out of fear for the house from corruption. This house, if it is corrupted, the whole body is corrupted, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Indeed in the body there is a morsel; if it is sound, the whole body is sound, and if it is corrupt, the whole body is corrupt. Indeed, it is the heart." So understand the preservation of these doors and be keen on it.

Looking is the beginning!:
Know that the beginning of disobedience is looking. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The glance is a poisoned arrow from the arrows of Iblis."

Jesus, peace be upon him's, opinion on the glance:
Jesus, peace be upon him, said: "Beware of the glance, for it sows regret in the heart."

And looking!:
Ibn Sirin said: "Beware of excess looking, for it leads to excess desire."
David said to his son: "O my son, walk behind a lion, but do not walk behind a woman."

Ibn Maktum looks at his feet!:
Al-Aswad ibn Maktum used to look at his feet when he walked. Perhaps women would meet him, so some of them would say to others: Let not the stature of Al-Aswad ibn Maktum scare you; when he walks, he looks at his feet, he does not look at you.

Islam urges protecting the woman:
In the Hadith: "The worst of women are those who adorn themselves for men and tempt men, and the worst of men are those who adorn themselves for women and are tempted."
From Ibn Umar - may Allah be pleased with him - he said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade that a man walk between two women." Narrated by Abu Dawood.
From Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The woman is Awrah (private/to be covered); when she goes out, the devil raises his head at her."
He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Keep distance between the breaths of men and the breaths of women."
And what was reported that "If a vein of a woman were in the East, and a vein of a man in the West, each one of them would yearn for its companion." So how about touching, speaking, and joking?! To Allah we belong and to Him we shall return over the lack of shame in committing sins.

The five that corrupt the heart:
It was narrated: "Five things corrupt the heart: Seclusion with women, listening to them, taking their opinion, debating with a fool—for if you debate him you become like him—and sitting with the dead. It was said: Who are the dead? He said: Every rich person whom his wealth has made arrogant, and every unjust leader."

text:
Are you two blind!!:
From Umm Salamah - may Allah be pleased with her - she said: I was with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Maymunah was with him. Ibn Umm Maktum approached, and that was after we were commanded with the hijab. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Veil yourselves from him." We said: O Messenger of Allah, is he not blind, unable to see us or recognize us? He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Are you two blind? Do you not see him?!"

The Adolescent and the Woman:
The more correct view is that the adolescent is like the adult; the woman must veil herself from him just as she must veil herself from the castrated man (majbub). It is obligatory upon the boy's guardian to prevent him from looking at her just as it is obligatory to prevent him from fornication.

Chapter
On the Doors of Disobedience

Ibn al-Qayyim describes the disease and the cure:
Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Most disobedience enters upon the servant through four doors, which are: Glances (Al-Lahzat), Thoughts (Al-Khatarat), Utterances (Al-Lafzat), and Steps (Al-Khutuwat). The servant should be the doorkeeper of himself at these four doors, and persist in guarding their breaches. Through them the enemy enters, roaming through the abodes and destroying whatever he overpowers with destruction.

Head of Desires!:
As for Glances: It is the scout of desire and its messenger. Guarding it is the basis of guarding the private part. Whoever releases his gaze, it leads him to the resources of destruction. Since the beginning of that is from looking, the command to lower it was placed before guarding the private part. He said: All incidents begin with the gaze, and most fire is from small sparks. So it becomes a look, then a thought, then a step/sin. Therefore it was said: Whoever guards these four has preserved his religion.

Lowering the gaze bequeaths sweetness in the heart:
Know that whoever lowers his gaze from the beauties of a woman or a beardless boy for the sake of Allah Almighty, Allah will bequeath in his heart a sweetness until the day he meets Him. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Beware of sitting on the roads." They said: O Messenger of Allah, our gatherings, we have no escape from them. He said: "If you must do so, then give the road its right." They said: What is its right? He said: "Lowering the gaze, refraining from harm, and returning the greeting."

Origin of general incidents:
Looking is the origin of most incidents that befall man. For the look generates a thought, then the thought generates an idea, then the idea generates a desire, then the desire generates a will, then it strengthens and becomes a firm resolve, so the action occurs inevitably unless something prevents it.

From the evils of looking:
Among the evils of looking is that it bequeaths regrets, sighs, and burning pains. The servant sees what he is not capable of [attaining], nor patient to stay away from, and you have no power over it. How many have sent their glances which did not return except leaving him floundering among them, slain. It is strange that the glance of the looker is an arrow that does not reach the looked-at until it occupies a place in the heart of the looker. Stranger than that is that the look wounds the heart a wound, then follows it with a wound upon a wound, yet the pain of the wounds does not prevent him from summoning its repetition. It has been said: Restraining glances is easier than constant regrets.

Thoughts are the origin of good and evil:
As for Thoughts: Their matter is more difficult, for they are the beginning of good and evil. From them wills, ambitions, and resolves are generated. Whoever watches his thoughts owns the reins of his self and conquers his desire. Whoever his thoughts overcome, his desire and self conquer him. Whoever takes thoughts lightly, they lead him forcibly to destruction. Thoughts continue to frequent the heart until they become vain hopes (Like a mirage in a lowland which a thirsty one thinks is water until, when he comes to it, he finds it is nothing but finds Allah before Him, He will pay him in full his due; and Allah is swift in account).

Whoever wastes his time, wastes his life!:
Know, O my brother, that time is a sword; if you do not cut it, it cuts you. So do not occupy your heart and limbs with what you do not possess of the matter of your religion and hereafter. You must think about the duty of the time and its function and focus all concern on it. For the knower (*Arif*) is the son of his time; if he wastes it, all his interests are wasted. All interests only arise from time; if he wastes it, he can never recover it.

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Al-Shafi'i's opinion on time:
Al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him, said: I accompanied the Sufis and did not benefit from them except for two letters [phrases]. One of them is their saying: Time is a sword; if you do not cut it, it cuts you. And he mentioned the other word. The time of a human is his life in reality, and it is the material of his eternal life in everlasting bliss, and the material of his miserable living in painful punishment. It passes faster than the passing of clouds. Whatever of his time was for Allah and by Allah is his life and age; other than that is not counted as part of his life, even if he lived long in it, he lives the life of beasts. If he cut his time in heedlessness, desire, and false hopes, and the best of his cutting it was in sleep and idleness, then death for this one is better than his life. And if the servant while in prayer has nothing of his prayer except what he comprehended of it, then he has nothing of his life except what he was in by Allah. Let the human know that there is no thought but it is written either as a good deed or a bad deed, and striving without need has been forbidden.

Choose your words well:
As for Utterances: Guarding them is by not letting out a wasted word; rather, he does not speak except in what he hopes for profit and increase in his religion. If he wants to speak a word, he looks: Is there benefit and profit in it or not? If there is no profit in it, he refrains from it. If there is profit in it, he looks: Will he miss by it a word that is more profitable? So he does not waste it with this one. If you want to infer what is in the hearts, infer it by the movement of the tongue, for it informs you of what is in the heart whether its owner wills or refuses.

The tongue reveals what is in the heart!:
Yahya bin Mu'adh said: "Hearts are like pots boiling with what is in them, and their tongues are their ladles. So look at the man when he speaks, for his tongue ladles out for you what is in his heart of sweet and sour, fresh and salty, and other than that. The ladling of his tongue clarifies for you the taste of his heart."

Entrance to Rectitude:
In the raised Hadith of Anas: "The faith of a servant is not straight until his heart is straight, and his heart is not straight until his tongue is straight."

Key to entering Hell:
The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked about what most admits people into Hell? He said: "The mouth and the private part."
In the two Sahihs: From the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "Indeed, a servant may speak a word from the pleasure of Allah Almighty, not paying attention to it, by which Allah raises him degrees. And indeed, a servant may speak a word from the wrath of Allah Almighty, not paying attention to it, by which he falls into Hell."
In Jami' al-Tirmidhi from the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: "A man from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, died, so a man said: 'Rejoice in Paradise!' The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Or do you not know? Perhaps he spoke about what did not concern him or was stingy with what did not decrease him.'" He said: A Hasan Hadith.
In the Sahih: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him say good or remain silent."
And in it is the Hadith: "Part of the perfection of a person's Islam is his leaving that which does not concern him."
And in a Hadith: "The speech of the son of Adam is against him, not for him, except commanding good, or forbidding evil, or the remembrance of Allah."
He said: The predecessors (Salaf), may Allah be pleased with them, and the successors (Khalaf) differed: Is everything he utters written? Or only good and evil? On two opinions: The more apparent is the first.
Some of the predecessors said: "All speech of the son of Adam is against him, not for him, except what was of the remembrance of Allah Almighty and what is allied to it."

Praiseworthy traits of the tongue:
Know that in the tongue are ten praiseworthy traits: A guide by which clarity appears. A witness of good about the conscience. A judge that decides the speech. A preacher that forbids the ugly. A speaker that returns the answer. An intercessor by whom need is attained. A describer by whom things are known. An expresser thanking Allah Almighty and the brothers. A praiser removing rancor. And a comforter entertaining the ears.
As for Steps: Guarding them is by not moving his foot except in what he hopes for its reward with Allah. If there is no increase of reward in his steps, then sitting is better for him. Since the slip is two slips: the slip of the leg and the slip of the tongue, one came coupled with the other in His saying, Exalted is He: (And when the ignorant address them [harshly], they say [words of] peace). So Allah described them with rectitude in their utterances and their steps, just as He combined glances and thoughts in His saying, Exalted is He: (He knows the treachery of the eyes and what the breasts conceal).

In leaving meddling is success for wisdom:

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Some of the Knowers (*Arifin*) said: "Whoever leaves excess speech is granted wisdom. Whoever leaves excess food is granted the sweetness of worship. Whoever leaves laughter is granted awe. Whoever leaves desire [for the world] is granted Paradise. Whoever leaves spying is granted the reformation of his own faults. Whoever leaves imagining the 'how-ness' of Allah's Essence is granted fear (*Khashyah*) and is safe from doubt and hypocrisy. And whoever leaves bad suspicion is granted safety from bad belief regarding creation."
It was said: Permissible looking affects just as impermissible looking affects. It is only permitted for teachers without persistence, and one might not look at all and looking may not be possible for him.
Know that your limbs have etiquettes related to them. Our Sheikh - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said in his book *Al-Hidayah*: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The emigrant (*Muhajir*) is the one who emigrates from evil, and the struggler (*Mujahid*) is the one who struggles against his desire."

Using Allah's blessings for His disobedience is the height of ingratitude:
Disobedience is only committed with the limbs, which are a blessing from Allah Almighty upon you, and a trust with you. So your using Allah's blessing for His disobedience is the height of ingratitude, and betraying a trust Allah entrusted to you is the height of tyranny. Your limbs are your subjects, so look how you tend them, for in the Hadith: "All of you are shepherds and each is responsible for his flock."

Work for a day when your limbs will testify against you:
Know that all your limbs will testify against you in the courts of Resurrection with a fluent tongue, exposing you before the heads of creation. Allah Almighty said: (That Day, We will seal over their mouths, and their hands will speak to Us, and their feet will testify about what they used to earn). And He said: (On a Day when their tongues, their hands and their feet will bear witness against them as to what they used to do).
So guard your entire body, especially the actions of your seven limbs, for Hell has seven gates, for each gate of them is a portion assigned. Only those who disobeyed Allah with these limbs are designated for those gates: The eye, the ear, the tongue, the hand, the belly, the private part, and the leg. For each limb of the limbs there are etiquettes specific to it.

Etiquettes of each limb:
The etiquettes of Sight are to look at his brothers with a look of affection and love, which they recognize from you and whoever attends the gathering. His look should be at his good qualities and the best thing that appears from him, and he should not turn his gaze away from him when he [the brother] turns to him. He should lighten his gaze from the adornments of the world, like decorated buildings and things the soul aspires to seek the like of, and which endear women to the heart. Allah Almighty said: (And do not extend your eyes toward that by which We have given enjoyment to [some] categories of them, [its being but] the splendor of worldly life).
Let man know that sight is a news-bringer that transfers the state of seen things to the heart, so their images are imprinted. Thus, the heart should be protected from transferring what it leads to, so it can be open for what emanates from it of thought and remembrance. Then it is established that the noblest of things is seeing Allah Almighty with the eyes in the Hereafter; so it is worthy for the owner of this hope to protect this organ for what he hopes for it of that virtue.
Etiquettes of Hearing: To listen to speech with a listening that desires what it hears, finding pleasure in it. When you speak to him, do not turn your gaze away from him, and do not interrupt his speech for any reason. If time compels you to something of that, inform him and show him your excuse! Beware of listening with it to a lute or flute, or listening with it to innovation, backbiting, obscenity, engaging in falsehood, mentioning people's faults, or other forbidden amusements, such as singing with poems that excite nature and desire, and listening to the speech of a foreign woman except for need. For a multitude of worshippers were tempted by speech just as others were tempted by sight.

Beware of Backbiting!:
As for listening to backbiting and the like, which is emphasized to avoid, it is not specific to the speaker without the listener. In the Hadith, the listener is a partner to the speaker, for the listener is one of the backbiters. So he should purify his hearing just as he purifies his sight, because it is a news-bringer that delivers the news of heard things to the heart.

Gardens of Musk are the reward for one who purified himself and his hearing from gatherings of amusement:
Muhammad ibn al-Munkadir, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said: "When it is the Day of Resurrection, a caller will call: Where are those who used to purify themselves and their hearing from gatherings of amusement and the flutes of devils? Make them dwell in the Gardens of Musk. Then He says to the angels: Make them hear My praise and glorification."

Etiquettes of the Tongue:

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
To speak to your brothers with what they love, offer them your advice, guide them to what contains their benefit, drop from your speech what you know your brother dislikes of talk, word, or otherwise. Do not raise your voice over him, do not address him with what he dislikes, speak to him according to the measure of his understanding and knowledge. Protect your tongue from backbiting, gossip, evil, obscenity, cursing, mockery, ridicule, lying, false testimony, spreading secrets, false praise, and the speech of the two-faced.

Faith... and the Tongue!:
When the evils of the tongue became many, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The faith of a servant is not straight until his heart is straight, and his heart is not straight until his tongue is straight."
He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "And does anything cast people into the Fire on their faces—or he said on their noses—except the harvests of their tongues?"

For whom Allah guaranteed Paradise:
He said: "Whoever guarantees for me what is between his jaws and between his legs, I guarantee for him Paradise."
Sufyan ibn Abdullah al-Thaqafi said: "O Messenger of Allah, what is the most fearful thing you fear for me? He took hold of his own tongue, then said: This."
In the two Sahihs: From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "Indeed, the servant speaks a word, by which he descends into the Fire farther than the distance between the East and the West."

Beware of Cursing:
In the Hadith: "The believer is not a defamer, nor a curser, nor obscene, nor vulgar." And in it: "When a servant curses something, the curse ascends to the sky, and the gates of the sky are closed against it. Then it takes right and left; if it finds no passage, it returns to the one who was cursed, if he was deserving of it, otherwise it returns upon its sayer."
From Abu Musa from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "If you are able not to curse anything, then do so. For if the curse exits from its sayer and the cursed one was deserving of it, it strikes him. If he was not deserving of it, and the curser was deserving of it, it returns upon him. If he was not deserving of it, it strikes a Jew, or a Christian, or a Magian. So if you are able not to curse anything, then do so."
In the Hadith of Bilal ibn al-Harith, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: "Indeed, a man speaks a word from the pleasure of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, not thinking it would reach where it reached, so Allah writes for him His pleasure until the Day of Resurrection. And indeed, a man speaks a word from the wrath of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, not thinking it would reach where it reached, so Allah writes against him His wrath until the Day of Resurrection."
Alqama - may Allah have mercy on him - used to say: How many words has the Hadith of Bilal ibn al-Harith, may Allah be pleased with him, prevented me from saying."
And Shumayt ibn Ajlan: "O son of Adam, as long as you are silent you are safe; if you speak, take your caution."

Boasting about Fathers:
Among what the tongue must be guarded from is boasting about fathers, especially fathers of the Jahiliyyah (Pre-Islamic era) and aggrandizement through them. That is not lawful due to His saying, Exalted is He: (O mankind, indeed We have created you from male and female and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another. Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you).

Specific to the Two Hands is refraining from striking with them in what is not lawful, touching what is not permissible, and cheating in measurement and weight. They even used to warn against clipping/pinching (?) with it. Harith, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Beware of thoughts/snatching(?), for a man's hand acts hypocritically among the rest of his body. Guard them from approaching a Muslim with them [harmfully], or taking with them what is forbidden, or harming anyone with them, or betraying a trust with them, or writing with them what is not permissible—for the pen is one of the two tongues. Extend your hand to your brothers with kindness and assistance, and do not withhold them from them and from bestowing upon them and helping them.
Specific to the Belly is leaving the consumption of unlawful things (Haram), adultery (metaphorical/related to desire), eating the wealth of the orphan, the usurped, and the stolen.

The Effects Resulting from Satiety:

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Be keen on seeking the lawful (Halal) and limit yourself from it to less than satiety. For satiety hardens the heart, corrupts the mind, nullifies memorization, distracts limbs from worship and knowledge, strengthens desires, and aids the armies of Satan. [Beware of] cutting off wealth with a false oath. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, cursed the consumer of usury (Riba) and its payer, and said: "A dirham of usury which a man eats—while he knows—is worse with Allah than thirty-six acts of adultery." He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever swears an oath by which he cuts off the wealth of a Muslim man will meet Allah Almighty while He is angry with him."
Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "A servant does not earn unlawful wealth and spend from it and it is blessed for him, nor does he give it in charity and it is accepted from him, nor does he leave it behind his back except that it is his provision to the Fire. Let one beware of consuming doubtful things, for they have an effect on the heart." The righteous predecessors—may Allah be pleased with them—used to leave seventy doors of the lawful for fear of falling into a door of doubt.

How are we able to guard the private part?:
Know that you cannot reach guarding the private part except by guarding the eye from looking, guarding the heart from thought, and guarding the belly from desires and from satiety. These are the movers of desire and its planting grounds. As for the Private Part: Guard it from everything Allah Almighty has forbidden. Allah Almighty said: (And who guard their private parts).
One cannot reach guarding the private part except by guarding the eye from looking, guarding the heart from thought, and guarding the belly from desires and from satiety. These are the movers of desire and its planting grounds. Among the greatest of what Al-Haytham ibn Malik al-Ta'i, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, is that he said: "There is no sin—after Shirk (associating partners) with Allah—greater with Allah than a drop [semen] a man places in a womb that is not lawful for him."

What most admits people to Paradise, and what most admits them to Hell:
Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he was asked about what most admits people to Paradise? He said: "Fear of Allah Almighty (Taqwa)." And he was asked about what most admits people to Hell? He said: "The private part and the mouth." Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "If adultery and usury appear in a town, Allah permits its destruction."
Etiquettes of the Two Legs: To walk with his brothers in the manner of a follower, not preceding them. If he brings him close to himself, he approaches to the extent he knows he needs, then returns to his place. He should not sit back from the rights of his brothers relying on trust in their brotherhood, for Al-Fudayl—may Allah be pleased with him—said: "Leaving the rights of brothers is humiliation." He stands for his brothers when he sees them approaching, and does not sit except when they sit, and sits where they seat him.
Guard your legs from walking with them to Haram or striving to the door of a ruler. For walking to unjust rulers without necessity or flattery is disobedience; it is humility and honoring of them, while Allah Almighty commanded turning away from them. It is increasing their numbers and aiding them in their injustice. If that was a means to seek their money, it is striving for Haram. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever humbles himself to a rich man, two-thirds of his religion is gone." This is regarding a righteous rich man, so what do you think of the unjust rich man?

Adultery of the Limbs:
Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "The eyes commit adultery and their adultery is looking, the feet commit adultery and their adultery is striving/walking, the legs commit adultery and their adultery is walking, the mouth commits adultery and its adultery is kissing, the heart desires and wishes, and the private part confirms that or denies it."
Let a human know that there is no step but it is written either as a good deed or a bad deed. Striving without need has been forbidden. So upon you, O my brother, is to restrain your senses and imprison your limbs, for they are counted against you. Count your breaths, and call yourself to account before the Day of Account.

The Caliph who calls himself to account:

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Call yourselves to account before you are called to account."
If you avoid [misusing] your limbs, you will be safe, Allah Almighty willing, from their evil. The most important of them is Looking, for its harm is great and its trial is immense. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever strikes a forbidden look at a woman, Allah will fill his eyes with fire on the Day of Resurrection, then he will be ordered to the Fire. And whoever is able to do so but leaves it, enters Paradise."
Hatim, may Allah have mercy on him, said: A man's adultery with a righteous woman is three things: Looking, Speaking, and Taking and Giving. If she looks at him and he looks at her and finds the sweetness of that, this is the adultery of the eye. If he says to her: O my sister, and she says to him: O my brother, and he finds the sweetness of that, this is the adultery of speech. If he gives her and takes, that is the adultery of Taking and Giving.
In the Hadith: "Whoever guards what is between his jaws and between his legs enters [Paradise]."
Dawud al-Ta'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "They used to dislike excess looking just as they disliked excess speech."
The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "No man is alone with a woman—who is not a Mahram—except that Satan is the third of them." Narrated by Al-Nasa'i.
He, upon him be blessings and peace, said: "Looking at a beautiful woman is a arrow from the arrows of Iblis."
From Abu Umamah al-Bahili, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever looks at the beauties of a woman then lowers his gaze at the first instance, Allah creates for him an act of worship whose sweetness he finds in his heart."

"Benefit": For one who fears temptation for himself!!:
If you look at a woman or other than her and fear temptation for yourself, turn your face away and say: As Yusuf, peace be upon him, said when he saw: "Protect me, O Allah, by Your mercy, O Most Merciful of the merciful." Due to His Almighty's saying: (Had he not seen the proof of his Lord) the verse.
Abu Ubaydah said regarding the Hadith of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "Al-Muka'amah and Al-Mukama'ah", Abu al-Nadr narrated it to me, from Al-Layth ibn Sa'd, from Abbas ibn Abbas who raised it [to the Prophet] and said: "Al-Muka'amah" is that a man kisses his companion. Taken from *ka'm al-ba'ir* (muzzling the camel), which is binding its mouth when it gets excited. It is said from it: *ka'amtuhu*. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, made kissing when he kisses him like the muzzle.
As for his saying: "Al-Mukama'ah", it is that a man lies with his companion in one garment. Taken from *Al-Kami'*, and *Al-Kami'* is the bedfellow. From it, a woman's husband is called: "her *Kami'* ".
He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A man should not lie with a man in one garment, nor should a woman lie with a woman in one garment." Narrated by Muslim.
He, peace and blessings be upon him, said regarding children: "Order them to pray at seven, beat them for [abandoning] it at ten, and separate between them in beds."
This is regarding a brother with his brother. So how about an ignorant fool and fools like him! They establish brotherhood in their claim, and think that this is permissible for them. Perhaps they make brotherhood a basis for the permissibility of each one of them to his companion, so the man says 'my sister', and the Sheikh 'my daughter', so they legitimize what Allah has forbidden of that, and expose themselves to Allah's wrath by doing that. We ask Allah for protection, success, and guidance to the path by His grace and generosity.

"Benefit" Regarding separation in beds:
Al-Husni said: If the boy and girl reach ten years, it is obligatory to separate between him and his mother and father, and his sister and brother in beds, due to the texts reported regarding that. Greater than that is the companionship of young boys (Ahdath).

Companionship of Young Boys is the strongest of Satan's traps:

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Sheikh Muhammad al-Mas'udi said: Abu al-Faraj ibn al-Jawzi, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said: Companionship of young boys (*Ahdath*) is the strongest of Satan's traps with which he hunts. The righteous predecessors used to exaggerate in turning away from beardless boys (*Murd*). For this reason, Mujahid narrated from Al-Sha'bi saying: "The delegation of Abd al-Qays came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and among them was a beardless boy of evident beauty. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, made him stand up from before him and seated him behind his back," distancing him from his sight. This is not what a group of the poor [Sufis] of the countryside do, sitting youths behind their backs continuously in the way of companionship and mixing—we seek refuge in Allah from that—and whoever does that has innovated.
Brothers, if the Master of Mankind warned against looking at a beardless boy with this caution, what do you think of the people of this time? In danger are hearts filled with desires, and bodies nourished with doubtful things and prohibitions. Is temptation in them anything but faster than the landing of a fly in honey? Does anyone dispute this except one whose mind is deranged? We ask Allah for safety.
Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Musa al-Wasiti said: "If Allah wants the humiliation of a servant, He throws him to these carcasses (jif)," meaning by that the attachment of the heart.
Abu al-Faraj said: Ibn al-Mubarak said: Sufyan al-Thawri entered the bathhouse, and a beautiful-faced boy entered upon him. He said: "Get him out, get him out! For I see with every woman a devil, and with every boy more than ten devils."
The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Do not sit with the sons of kings, for souls yearn for them with a yearning they do not have for freed slave-girls."
From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "Do not fill your eyes with the sons of kings, for they have a temptation stronger than virgins."

Chapter
On How a Boy Should Be

A boy should have much modesty (*Haya'*), and little mixing with strangers. Wahb ibn Munabbih said: If a boy has two traits: Modesty and Fear/Reverence (*Rahba*), his good is hoped for.
Umar ibn al-Khattab said: "I do not fear for a scholar from a predatory beast more than I fear for him from a beardless boy."
Al-Hasan ibn Dhakwan said: "Do not sit with the children of the rich, for they have images like the images of women, and they are a stronger temptation than virgins."
Some of them said: "All incidents are from looking."
Abu Ali al-Rudhbari, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Ahmad al-Mu'addib, may Allah have mercy on him, said to me: We have seen those stronger in faith than the Sufis, yet when he sees a young boy approaching, he flees from him like his fleeing from a lion!

Chapter
On the Qualities in which Looking at Women and Hearing their Voice is Permissible

Qualities permitting looking:
Know that looking at women intentionally is not permissible except for four qualities: When intending marriage, when testifying against her, if they are Mahrams (unmarriageable kin) to him such as the mother, sister, maternal aunt, and paternal aunt, and the husband's looking at the wife.

When hearing her voice is permissible:
Hearing her voice is not permissible except in certain things: in selling, buying, asking for a fatwa (religious ruling), litigation, testimony, and narration.

Ruling on a man looking at a woman:
Sheikh Taqi al-Din ibn al-Husni said: A man's looking at a foreign woman (Ajnabiyyah) is of seven types:
One of them: A look at a foreign woman without need. This is not permissible for the adult male, and likewise the woman, meaning the adult female. Furthermore, looking is either not called for by need, or it may be called for by need.
First Type: That no need calls for it. In this case, it is forbidden for a man to look at the 'Awrah of a slave-girl if he fears temptation. If he does not fear temptation, contrary to the correct view [which forbids it], the prohibition was stated by Al-Istakhri and Abu Ali al-Tabari, and chosen by Sheikh Abu Muhammad. Sheikh Abu Ishaq al-Shirazi stated it definitively, and Al-Ruyani. The Imam justified it by the consensus of Muslims on preventing women from going out [unveiled], and that looking is a presumptive cause of temptation and a stirrer of desire. So it is more fitting for the beauties of the Sharia to block this door and turn away from details of conditions, just as seclusion with a foreign woman is forbidden. He argued for it with the generality of His Almighty's saying: (Tell the believing men to reduce [some] of their vision and guard their private parts).

Ruling on the adolescent's looking:

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Does the adolescent have the right to look? There are two views, the more correct of which is: His looking is like the looking of an adult due to his exposure to the Awrahs of women, meaning he is like an adult; a woman must veil herself from him just as she is definitively required to veil herself from a castrated man (*Majbub*). The guardian is obligated to prevent him from looking just as he prevents him from adultery and other prohibitions.
As for the ruling on the *Mamsuh* (one with erased genitals), who is the eunuch (*Tawashi*), some said: He is like the *Majbub*, so he is prevented from looking.
Know that the one whose penis only is cut off, or whose testicles only are removed, and the impotent (*'Innin*), and the decrepit old man—their ruling is the ruling of the potent male according to what the majority said.
As for a woman's slave, meaning her bondsman: He is like a foreign man (*Ajnabi*), so it is forbidden for him to look [at her], and forbidden for her, and veiling from him is obligatory. For this reason, if he touched her or she touched him, wudu is definitively broken. Al-Nawawi said: Al-Imrani and others stated clearly that the female slave is like the free woman, which is the implication of the disagreement among many, and it is the preponderant view by evidence. Even if the free woman is old, Al-Ghazali appended her to the young woman. He said: Because desire is not regulated, and she is a locus for intercourse. Qadi Husayn said: Old women who apply kohl to men on the day of Ashura are committing Haram. Al-Husni said this in the explanation of Abu Shuja'.

Second Type: His looking at his wife and his slave-girl. It is permissible to look at everything except the private part of them. It is permissible for a man to look at the entire body of his wife because it is permissible to enjoy her. Likewise the slave-girl in that, whether she is a pure slave (*Qinna*), a *Mudabbara* (freed upon death), or an *Umm Walad* (mother of a child). Know that a wife's looking at her husband is like his looking at her.

Third Type: His looking at his Mahrams, or his married slave-girl. It is permissible regarding what is other than [between] the navel and the knee.

Fourth Type: Looking for the sake of marriage. It is permissible [to look] at the face and hands. It was mentioned that looking may not be called for by need, or need may touch upon it. It was mentioned in the First Type and Second Type what need touches upon. Need includes several matters, among them: Intention of marriage. If a man wants to marry a woman he desires, there is no doubt about the permissibility of looking at her. This is recommended due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, to Al-Mughira: "Look at her, for it is more likely to bring harmony between you." Narrated by Al-Nasa'i and Ibn Majah, and Al-Tirmidhi declared it Hasan, and Ibn Hibban and Al-Hakim, who said: On the condition of the two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim), and other reports. It is permissible to repeat looking, whether he looks with her permission or without her permission. If it is not easy for him, he sends a woman to observe her and describe her to him; because he, upon him be peace, sent Umm Sulaym to a woman and said: "Look at her achilles tendon and smell her sides (mouth/neck)." Then looking at her hand, back and palm. He does not look at other than that. In one view, he looks at her like a man looks at a man. This looking is permitted. The time of looking is after resolving to marry her, and before the proposal, lest he leave her after the proposal and hurt her. This is the correct view. It was said he looks when permission is given for the marriage contract. It was said upon the inclination of each one to the other. If he looks and she does not please him, let him be silent and not say: I do not want her, for it is hurtful. And Allah knows best.

Fifth Type: Looking for medical treatment at the places needed. Among the places of need is looking at a foreign woman due to her need for phlebotomy or cupping or treating that, because Umm Sulaym, may Allah be pleased with her, asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, for permission for cupping, so the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered "Abu Taybah to cup her." Narrated by Muslim. Let that be in the presence of a Mahram or husband in case of seclusion, and on the condition that the doctor is not a Dhimmi (non-Muslim subject) while a Muslim exists.

Sixth Type: Looking for testimony and business dealing (*Makatabah*?). It is permissible to look at the face specifically. Among the places of need: Permissibility of looking at the breast of a wet nurse for the purpose of testifying to breastfeeding. Likewise looking at the private parts of fornicators; for the purpose of testifying against them, because need calls for that.

Seventh Type: Looking at a slave-girl when buying her. It is permissible to look at the places needed in examining her, from the places of need. And Allah knows best.

Notice on explaining Awrahs and their rulings

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Our Sheikh said: Know that the Awrah (intimate parts/nakedness) of a man is from his navel to his knee. This is the limit of the man's Awrah regarding a man, and the woman regarding a woman. As for the woman regarding a foreign man: She is all Awrah unless she is a slave-girl, so the limit of her Awrah regarding a man is like the limit of a man's Awrah with a man, except that it is disliked for him to look at what is forbidden for him regarding a [free] woman, for fear of temptation.
As for Mahrams (unmarriageable kin): It is permissible to look from them at what is customarily exposed, like the hands, feet, part of the shin, and part of the forearm. This was pardoned only due to hardship.
As for the Awrah of a Muslim woman regarding a Dhimmi woman: It is like the Awrah of a woman with a man.
The Man: As for looking at the Awrah of a child below seven years, the ruling of Awrah is not established for him. Thus, it is permissible for a woman to wash him, and for a man to wash a girl if she is below seven years. What is emphasized to lower the gaze from—especially in the bathhouse—is the beardless boy (*Amrad*), especially the beautiful of image.
The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Ali, may Allah honor his face: "Do not follow a glance with a glance, for the first is for you and the other is not for you."
It was said: Ibrahim ibn Adham wrote to Sufyan al-Thawri: "Whoever unleashes a glance, his regret is prolonged. Whoever unleashes his hope, his deed becomes bad. Whoever unleashes his tongue, kills himself."
He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Looking at the beauties of a beardless boy is a poisoned arrow." It is forbidden for the guardian to enable him to enter with a man or men who are not Mahrams to him, because seclusion with a beardless boy is like seclusion with a woman, as Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned in his Fatwas.
It is forbidden for a man and a woman to look at the face of a beardless boy with desire. Her looking is [forbidden] according to the correct view. A woman is forbidden from looking at other than her husband unless he is someone permissible to look at. It is forbidden for her to look from a woman at what is between her navel and her knee. The more correct view is the prohibition of a disbelieving woman looking at the body of a Muslim woman. It is forbidden for a Muslim woman to uncover in the presence of a Kitabi (Christian/Jewish) woman. It is forbidden to enter the bathhouse with Kitabi women and Harbi (women at war) women. If she enters with them, she must cover her entire body except what appears during work, nothing else.
Imam Allamah Sheikh Izz al-Din ibn Abd al-Salam said: The sinful woman (*Fasiqa*) has the ruling of the Dhimmi woman in that. Those in authority should be keen to prevent Dhimmi and sinful women from entering the bathhouse with chaste believing women. If that is difficult due to the lack of concern of those in authority in denouncing that, let the free believing woman guard herself from the disbeliever and the sinner.
From Qays ibn al-Harith, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, wrote to Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah: It has reached me that Muslim women in your region enter bathhouses with polytheist women. He forbade that with strict prohibition, for it is not lawful for a woman who believes in Allah and the Last Day that her Awrah be seen by other than the people of her religion, and that nothing of her body be seen other than the face and hands outside the bathhouse. Abu Ubaydah said—while angry, and he was not prone to anger—: "O Allah, any woman who enters the bathhouse without illness or sickness, intending thereby to whiten her face, may Allah not whiten her face on the day faces are whitened."
As for the slave-girl, it is forbidden for other than her master to look at her. The forearm of a free woman, her head hair, the pubic hair of a man and similar things are forbidden [to look at] when attached, and likewise when detached according to the more correct view. Also according to the more correct view, it is forbidden to look at the nail clippings of a woman's foot, not her hand clippings. It is disliked for a man and a woman to look at their own private parts without need.
As for the spouses looking at each other's private parts: There are two views: One is prohibition, and one is dislike, except the "anal ring". It is forbidden for a man to touch a man's thigh without a barrier, and likewise from over a garment if he fears temptation. It is forbidden to touch everything permissible to look at of Mahrams; so it is not permissible for a man to touch his mother's belly or back, nor to press her shin or leg, nor to kiss her face. Likewise, it is not permissible to order his daughter or sister to press his legs or massage him.
Ibn al-Hajj said: It is not permissible for one covering his Awrah to gather with one uncovering his Awrah under one roof.

Places where uncovering Awrah is permissible:
Know that uncovering Awrah is not permissible except in four places: During intercourse under a cover, during relieving oneself inside a toilet or covering the Awrah in the open/desert, or during washing oneself covered in a private place or otherwise—and if one washed while covering the Awrah it is permissible—and upon seeing a doctor. Uncovering is permissible in these states for the duration of the need in all these states. Exceeding the amount of need is forbidden according to the more correct view, because covering the Awrah in seclusion is obligatory according to the more correct view, mentioned by Al-Nawawi in Sharh Muslim. It is forbidden to look with desire at other than a beardless boy, men, Mahrams, old men, and old women.

Looking into people's houses:

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
As for looking into people's houses without their permission, it is forbidden. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever looks into the house of a people without their permission, it becomes lawful for them to gouge out his eye." Narrated by Muslim. He also said: "If a man looked at you without permission and you threw a pebble at him and gouged out his eye, there would be no sin upon you." Agreed upon.

Chapter
On the Etiquettes of Boys Entering the Bathhouse

As for boys entering the bathhouse with each other: It is possible that it is like women entering with each other, so it is permissible. And it is possible that it is like men too, so it is permissible. The better course is not to mix them in entering for fear of corruption.
As for the adult *Mamsuh* (eunuch), some permitted it and some forbade it. Likewise the *Majbub* whose testicles remain, the castrated one (*Khasi*) whose penis remains, the impotent (*'Innin*) incapable of intercourse, the effeminate (*Mukhannath*), and the decrepit old man. A group permitted these to look at women, and others forbade it. Those who permitted it said: They are not of those possessing desire (*Uli al-Irbah*). Those who forbade it said: Because of the generality of His Almighty's saying: (Tell the believing men to reduce [some] of their vision), the verse. This is the truth that is issued as fatwa.
Ibn al-Sabbagh, may Allah have mercy on him, said: It is not permissible for a castrated man to look at the body of a foreign woman unless he becomes old and decrepit, and his desire goes away. Likewise the effeminate. Seclusion with a foreign woman is forbidden, whether in a bathhouse, a house, or a road.
Abu Zakariya al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in *Al-Rawdah*: The narration from the Companions [of the Shafi'i school] is that it is not permissible for a man to be alone with one woman, but it is permissible for a man to be alone with two trustworthy women, because a woman's shyness from another woman is greater than a man's shyness from another man.

States of the Ambiguous Hermaphrodite (*Khuntha Mushkil*):
As for the ambiguous hermaphrodite, he has states:
First: To enter the bathhouse with a woman. This is forbidden; because of the possibility of being a man, and seclusion with her is forbidden.
Second: To enter with two men or men. This is also forbidden; because of the possibility of being a woman.
Third: To enter with two women or women. That is permissible; because a man's seclusion with women is permissible according to the correct view.
Fourth: To enter the bathhouse with a hermaphrodite. This is forbidden because of the possibility one is male and the other female.
Fifth: To be with two hermaphrodites or hermaphrodites. This is forbidden.

Notices:
First: The repetition of verses, hadiths, and similar chapters in this book is for an added benefit or a returning utility.
Second: This book is set forth by way of exhortation and warning, so there is no objection if speech moves from his school of thought (Madhhab) to the school of another, because speech in exhortation is not restricted to the speaker's Madhhab. Our Sheikh was asked: Why do you speak in the Madhhab of others or why do you exit your Madhhab? He said: If the speaker is in exhortation, he has the right to speak in the four Madhhabs, but if he is in a Fiqh lesson, he does not exit his Madhhab.

Chapter
Comprehensive on Clarifying the Sunnah regarding Conditions Related to Youths and Women in their Gathering in Noble Places and Others, and What They Are Commanded and Forbidden

Know that the Sunnah when women and youths are present in prayer, whether in a mosque or elsewhere, is that the people of knowledge and Sheikhs stand behind the Imam, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Let those of you who possess dreams (maturity) and intelligence be near me." Then the general public behind them right and left. Youths stand behind them, then women behind the youths. If a youth advances in front of the men, he is ordered to move back behind them, like his action, peace and blessings be upon him, when he made a youth stand up from before him and seated him behind him. This was not during prayer, so it is more appropriate regarding him to delay in prayer. And Allah knows best.
As for the evidence for delaying youths behind men in prayer, it is what was narrated from Anas ibn Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that his grandmother Mulaykah invited the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, to food she made. He ate from it then said: "Stand up so I may pray for you." Anas said: So I stood up to a mat of ours that had turned black from long use, so I sprinkled it with water. He, peace and blessings be upon him, stood on it, and I and the orphan aligned behind him, and the old woman behind us. He prayed two rak'ahs with us and left, peace and blessings be upon him. In Muslim: "That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed with him and his mother, so he placed me on his right, and placed the woman behind us."
From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The best rows for men are the first ones and the worst are the last ones, and the best rows for women are the last ones and the worst are the first ones." Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, and Al-Nasa'i.
The Sunnah in their sitting in circles of Dhikr: If men and youths are present, the Sunnah is that men form a circle, then youths form a circle behind them. That is further from temptation and safer for hearts. It is an etiquette regarding youths; and men must lower their gazes from the youths facing them, and that is a condition in Dhikr.

The Sunnah in their gatherings in schools (Makatib):

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Our Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, said: It is appropriate for the Faqih (teacher) to adopt a spacious place to teach the Quran in, to sit for reading while in a state of purity, and to tend to the children with the eye of care, due to the Hadith "Every shepherd is responsible for his flock." He should not let the boys mix with each other, except for some to teach others. The Sunnah, if he has women and boys, is that each sit alone and separate some from others.
Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, said: I dislike for the teacher to teach women. If he teaches them, he should not let them sit with the boys, for fear they might corrupt [them]. It is appropriate for the teacher, whether in a mosque or elsewhere, to be trustworthy, chaste, pious, preserving [himself], married. He should not look at a boy without need; if he looks at him without need, that is forbidden for him, and touching him is forbidden. If the teacher fears temptation for himself, he puts the boy behind him and teaches him. He said: Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, used to seat "Muhammad ibn al-Hasan" behind him then teach him, out of fear of temptation and following the Sunnah.
The monitor (*Arif*) should not enable isolating with a boy in a place alone for the sake of learning; rather, they should all sit in the presence of the Faqih. He should not permit two boys to go out to relieve themselves, but one after another. If he sees two gathered without necessity, he separates them after frightening them, forbidding them, and teaching them what they need of religious matters. He prevents them from erasing the Quran with spit. The Sunnah is to make for them a container with water in which they wipe their tablets. If it becomes black, he orders them to pour it into the flowing sea. Our Faqih - may Allah have mercy on him - used to order us to do that. If there is no sea or river there, he orders them to dig a small hole in the ground and pour the water into it. It is not appropriate for the teacher to teach a girl "Surah Yusuf". It was narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Teach them spinning, do not house them in upper rooms, and do not teach them writing." Narrated by Al-Bazzar.

Chapter
On What is Permissible for the Faqih Regarding Beating the Boy

The scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, said: It is permissible for the Faqih to beat with conditions:
First: That it not be with something that wounds the body.
Second: That it not break a bone.
Third: That the beating be beneficial and useful; if it is not useful, beating is not permissible.
Fourth: That he is not deterred without beating, such as by intimidation, threat, and the like. Punishment by biting is not lawful, because it is not permitted in any form except in necessity.
Fifth: That the beating not be on the face.
Sixth: That it not be on a fatal spot.
Seventh: That it be for the benefit of the boy. If the guardian disciplines him for his benefit, or the Faqih for a benefit other than the benefit of the minor, it is not permissible, because it is forbidden to use him for his needs by which the boy's interests are missed.
Eighth: That it be after discernment (*Tamyiz*). Discernment is at seven years usually; it may be before that or delayed. The criterion is understanding speech, returning an answer, going to the toilet for urine and feces, and covering the Awrah. Whenever that is found in him, he has discerned. If he reaches ten years, it is obligatory to beat him for prayer.

The Sunnah regarding their going up the minaret for Adhan:
If there is a mu'adhin among them, the Sunnah is not to enable youths to go up the minaret with one man, for seclusion with a beardless boy is forbidden just as seclusion with a foreign woman is forbidden. Nor with two men, unless he is alone so he is permitted to ascend the minaret. For his seclusion with two men is forbidden like the seclusion of two men with a woman, and that is also forbidden.
Our Sheikh said in *Risalat al-Nur*: It is forbidden for the boy's guardian to enable him to be alone with a man or men who are not his Mahrams, just as it is forbidden for him to enable him to enter the bathhouse with a man or men who are not his Mahrams, because seclusion with a beardless boy is like seclusion with a woman, as Al-Nawawi mentioned in his Fatwas. He restricted the prohibition of looking in his book *Al-Riyad* and *Al-Tibyan* to when he is handsome. Some said: Especially if he is plump, or from the boys of this time in general, be they Turks, Arabs, urbanites, or others. However, if a group of youths have a habit of ascending the minaret intending Adhan, it is permissible—with safety from corruption—for them together. If corruption is not safe, they are prevented from going up. Their entering the bathhouse is analogous.

Boys entering the bathhouse with each other:
Our Sheikh said: As for boys entering the bathhouse with each other: It is possible that it is like women entering with each other, so it is permissible. And it is possible that it is like men too, so it is permissible. The better course is not to mix boys in entering; because corruption often occurs between them. If that is verified, they are prevented. It is forbidden for the guardian to enable the boy to enter with foreign men. And Allah knows best.

Clarification of Interests and Harms in Entering the Bathhouse, What is Disliked for Men, and What is Forbidden for Women Except for Necessity!

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Our Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Al-Hafiz Abu Nu'aym mentioned in the book *Al-Tibb al-Nabawi* from Tawus from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Beware of a house called the Hammam (Bathhouse)." They said: O Messenger of Allah, it removes dirt and benefits the sick. He said: "So whoever enters it, let him cover himself."
Know that among the greatest corruptions necessitating cursing is entering the bathhouse without a waistcloth (*Mi'zar*). In the Hadith: "Allah cursed the looker and the looked at."
From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade men and women from bathhouses. Then he permitted men to enter them in waistcloths." Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and others.
The scholars said: This is if he enters it to remove dirt, clean himself, and the like. If he enters it without need, but intending luxury and adornment for worldly purposes. Our Sheikh said: The apparent meaning of Al-Ghazali's words in *Al-Ihya* and Abu Bakr al-Sam'ani is that it is disliked.
It was narrated from Ali and Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both: "What a miserable house is the bathhouse; it reveals the Awrah and removes modesty."
Imam Ahmad narrated with his chain to Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: O people, I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saying: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not sit at a table where wine is circulated. Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not enter the bathhouse except with a waistcloth. And whoever [female] believes in Allah and the Last Day, let her not enter the bathhouse."

Chapter
On Preventing Women from Entering the Bathhouse

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Any woman who removes her clothes in other than her husband's house has torn her veil between her and Allah." This chain is authentic (Sahih).
In Sahih Ibn Hibban from the Hadith of Abu Ayyub al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him honor his neighbor. Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not enter the bathhouse except with a waistcloth. Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him say good or remain silent. And whoever among your women believes in Allah and the Last Day, let her not enter the bathhouse."
All these traditions indicate prohibiting the permissibility of the bathhouse for men [without covering] and for women.
Our Sheikh said: Sheikh Shihab al-Din ibn al-Imad said: Entering the bathhouse may become obligatory in some situations, which is entering for washing from Janabah (major impurity), menstruation, and postpartum bleeding, where washing outside is impossible for some reason.
It may become recommended, such as if he enters for a recommended wash like washing for the two Eids, Friday, and others, or to remove dirt that harms him to an extent preventing Khushu' (humility) in prayer and he could not wash outside, or inside for healing from a disease or harm.
It may become disliked, such as if he enters it for a corrupt purpose as preceded, or enters it between Maghrib and Isha, or before sunset, or enters it while fasting, or enters it while afflicted.
Dislike may arise for him from a medical perspective due to fever, disease, swelling, humors, or entering it while full before digesting food.
It may become forbidden, such as if he enters with uncovered Awrah, or enters where one who does not cover his Awrah is, or as a tool to enter into a forbidden seclusion like seclusion with a handsome beardless boy; so entering becomes forbidden due to these causes.
As for clarifying the permissibility of women entering it after their prohibition from it, the opinions of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, differed regarding the permissibility of entering for them.
First: Absolute permissibility, which is the opinion of Abu Darda, Ibn Abbas, and others.
Second Opinion: Absolute prohibition. This is narrated from Ibn Umar; it was narrated from him that he said: "The bathhouse is of the luxury they invented." This implies leaving it is better.
Third: Prohibition except for a sick woman or a woman in postpartum. This is narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to his companions: "You will conquer the land of the Persians, and in it are houses called 'Bathhouses' (Hammamat). It is forbidden for the men of my nation except with a waistcloth, and for the women of my nation except a woman in postpartum or sick." Narrated by Abu Dawood and others.
Al-Ruyani transmitted from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: It is absolutely forbidden for them to enter except for necessity.
The author of *Al-Faiq fi al-Lafz al-Ra'iq* said from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There will be bathhouses after me, and there is no good in bathhouses for women."
Al-Hafiz Abu Nu'aym narrated in *Tarikh Asbahan* from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "A house in Syria; it is not lawful for believing men to enter it except with a waistcloth, and it is not lawful for believing women to enter it at all." If necessity calls her, entering is permissible. Al-Ghazali, may Allah have mercy on him, said: In that case, she enters with a covering waistcloth.
Fourth Opinion: Prohibition for women absolutely, unlike men [who can enter] with a waistcloth.
From Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The woman is Awrah; when she goes out, the devil raises his head at her. The closest she is to her Lord is when she is in the depth of her house." Narrated by Ibn Majah in his Sunan and Ibn Hibban in his Sahih and others.
Al-Baghawi corrected in *Al-Rawdah* the permissibility of entering for a woman absolutely with dislike.

book_title: Salwat al-Ahzan lil-Ijtinab 'an Majalisat al-Ahdath wal-Niswan
text:
Sheikh Shihab al-Din ibn al-Imad said regarding the opinion of absolute permissibility: She is only permitted to enter with conditions:
First: That the husband permits her in that. If the husband does not permit her, entering is forbidden for her. He said: It is disliked for the husband to permit her in it. Al-Ghazali, may Allah have mercy on him, said in *Al-Ihya*: It is disliked for him to pay the fee for her, because he helps her in the disliked. This is if she intended entering for luxury. If her necessity called for her entering to wash from menstruation, postpartum bleeding, Janabah, or dirt, and she could not wash outside, he must enable her to enter.
